dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feather floats through the air. The falling feather. A city, Savannah, is revealed in the background. The feat floats down toward the city below. The feather drops down toward the street below, as people walk past and cars dri by, and nearly lands on a man's shoulder. He walks across the street, causing the feather to be whi back on its journey. The feather floats above a stopped c The car drives off right as the feather floats down towar the street. The feather floats under a passing car, then is sent flyi back up in the air. A MAN sits on a bus bench. The feathe floats above the ground and finally lands on the man's  mudsoaked shoe. The man reached down and picks up the feather. His name i FORREST GUMP. He looks at the feather oddly, moves aside box of chocolates from an old suitcase, then opens the ca Inside the old suitcase are an assortment of clothes, a  pingpong paddle, toothpaste and other personal items. Forrest pulls out a book titled "Curious George," then pl the feather inside the book. Forrest closes the suitcase. Something in his eyes reveals that Forrest may not be all there. Forrest looks right as the sound of an arriving bus is he A bus pulls up. Forrest remains on the bus bench as the b continues on. A BLACK WOMAN in a nurse's outfit steps up and sits down the bus bench next to Forrest. The nurse begins to read a magazine as Forrest looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. My name's Forrest Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a box of chocolates and holds it out for the nur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse shakes her head, a bit apprehensive about this  strange man next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could eat about a million and a  half of these. My momma always said,  "Life was like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna  get."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest eats a chocolate as he looks down at the nurse's  shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those must be comfortable shoes.  I'll bet you could walk all day in  shoes like that and not feel a thing.  I wish I had shoes like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feet hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma always says there's an awful  lot you could tell about a person by  their shoes. Where they're going. Where they've been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black woman stares at Forrest as he looks down at his own shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've worn lots of shoes. I bet if I  think about it real hard I could  remember my first pair of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest closes his eyes tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma said they'd take my anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little boy closes his eyes tightly. It is young Forrest he sits in a doctor's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said they was my magic shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest has been fitted with orthopedic shoes and metal l braces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Forrest, you can open  your eyes now. Let's take a little  walk around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor sets Forrest down on its feet. Forrest walks a stiffly. Forrest's mother, MRS. GUMP, watches him as he c around the room awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do those feel? His legs are  strong, Mrs. Gump. As strong as I've  ever seen. But his back is as crooked  as a politician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest walks foreground past the doctor and Mrs. Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're gonna straighten him right  up now, won't we, Forrest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud thud is heard as, outside, Forrest falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and young Forrest walk across the street. Forre walks stiffly next to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, when I was a baby, Momma named  me after the great Civil War hero,  General Nathan Bedford Forrest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black and white photo of General Nathan Bedford Forrest The photo turns into live action as the General dons a ho sheet over his head. The General is in full Ku Klux Klan garb, including his h The General rides off, followed by a large group of Klan  members dressed in full uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said we was related to him in  some way. And, what he did was, he  started up this club called the Ku  Klux Klan. They'd all dress up in  their robes and their bedsheets and  act like a bunch of ghosts or spooks  or something. They'd even put  bedsheets on their horses and ride  around. And anyway, that's how I got  my name. Forrest Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma said that the Forrest part was  to remind me that sometimes we all  do things that, well, just don't  make no sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest stops suddenly as his brace gets stuck. Forrest's brace is caught in a gutter grate. Mrs. Gump bends down a tries to free Forrest. Two old cronies sit in front of a  barber shop and watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait, let me get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump struggles to pull the stuck brace from the grat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get it. Wait, get it this  way. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest pulls his foot out of the grate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump helps Forrest up onto the sidewalk. She looks u and notices the two old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh. All right. What are you all  staring at? Haven't you ever seen a  little boy with braces on his legs  before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk along the sidewalk past the tw old men. Mrs. Gump holds tightly onto Forrest's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever let anybody tell you  they're better than you, Forrest. If  God intended everybody to be the  same, he'd have given us all braces  on our legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma always had a way of explaining  things so I could understand them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk along a dirt road. A row of  mailboxes stands left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lived about a quarter mile of  Route 17, about a half mile from the  town of Greenbow, Alabama. That's in  the county of Greenbow. Our house  had been in Momma's family since her  grandpa's grandpa's grandpa had come  across the ocean about a thousand  years ago. Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk along the Gump Boarding House  driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since it was just me and Momma and  we had all these empty rooms, Momma  decided to let those rooms out. Mostly  to people passing through. Like from,  oh, Mobile, Montgomery, place like  that. That's how me and Mommy got  money. Mommy was a real smart lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what I told you, Forrest. You're no different than anybody  else is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump heads Forrest to the porch. She bends down to l Forrest in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said, Forrest? You're the same as everybody else.  You are no different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boy's... different, Mrs. Gump. Now, his I.Q. is seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're all different, Mr. Hancock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal sighs, then stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sits outside the principal's office and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanted me to have the finest  education, so she took me to the  Greenbow County Central School. I  met the principal and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal stands in front of Mrs. Gump. Forrest, sitt left, listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show you something, Mrs. Gump. Now, this is normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal holds up a chart with a designations accord to I.Q. and points to the center of the graph, labeled  "Normal." A red line below the normal area is labeled "St Acceptance." The principal points to the section below th acceptance line labeled "Below."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest is right here. The state  requires a minimum I.Q. of eighty to  attend public school, Mrs. Gump. He's gonna have to go to a special  school. Now, he'll be just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does normal mean, anyway? He  might be a bit on the slow side, but  my boy Forrest is going to get the  same opportunities as everyone else. He's not going to some special school  to learn to how to re-tread tires.  We're talking about five little points  here. There must be something can be  done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sits outside the principal's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a progressive school system. We don't want to see anybody left  behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a Mr. Gump, Mrs. Gump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sits on a swing outside the house. Loud organic m grunts are heard coming from inside the house. Forrest si on the swing as the grunts continue. The principal steps of the Gump House and wipes the sweat from his face. Forrest is sitting on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your momma sure does care about  your schooling, son. Mm-mm-mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal wipes the sweat from his neck, then looks b at Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say much, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest grunts, imitating him. The principal, embarrassed turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump reads from the book "Curious George" as Forrest sits on the bed and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, he had to try it. It looked  easy, but, oh, what happened. First  there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma, what's vacation mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Daddy went?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation's when you go somewhere,  and you don't ever come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest lies down on his bed and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I guess you could say me and  Momma was on our own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab driver closes the trunk of the car as two women wal toward the house. A milkman steps down from the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we didn't mind. Our house was  never empty. There was always folks  comin' and goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump steps forward and speaks to all the boarders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's suppa, everyone. Forrest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN WITH A CANE steps left across the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, my. That sure looks special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump looks into a sitting room and informs the board about dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, would you care to join us  for supper? Hurry up and get it before  the flies do. I prefer you don't  smoke that cigar so close to mealtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we had so many people  stayin' with us that every room was  filled with travelers. You know,  folks livin' out of their suitcases,  and hat cases, and sample cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you go ahead and start. I can't  find Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump walks up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest... Forrest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One time a young man was staying  with us, and he had him a guitar  case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump looks into Forrest's room. She hears singing co from another room and walks over to a closed door. Mrs. G opens the door, revealing a young man with long sideburns he plays the guitar and sings. Forrest holds onto a broom and dances oddly. The young man is ELVIS PRESLEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "Well, you ain't never caught a  rabbit, and you ain't no friend of  mine."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest's legs rock back and forth to the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest! I told you not to bother  this nice young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, that's all right, ma'am. I  was just showin' him a thing or two  on the guitar here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but your supper's ready  if y'all want to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that sounds good. Thank you,  ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump leaves and closes the door. Elvis sits back dow Forrest stands left, and looks himself in a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, man, show me that crazy little  walk you just did there. Slow it  down some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest begins to dance again as Elvis plays the guitar a sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "You ain't nothin' but a hound, hound  dog..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked that guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest dances as he watches himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounded good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "...cryin' all the time"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest rocks up and down on his braced legs, then begins step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "You ain't nothin' but a hound dog..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started moving around to the music,  swinging my hips. This one night me  and Momma...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk along a sidewalk. A television inside a store window reveals Elvis Presley as he perform "Houng Dog" on a stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...was out shoppin', and we walked  right by Benson's Furniture and  Appliance store, and guess what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television reveals Elvis as he thrusts his hips and s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) You ain't nothin' but a hound dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest watch the television. Elvis dances  around in the same manner Forrest did. A woman in the aud screaming and applauding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) You ain't nothin' but a hound dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not children's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump walks away, pulling Forrest with her. Forrest s and takes one last look. Elvis continues to perform over television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "Well, you ain't never caught a rabbit  and you ain't no friend of mine."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some years later, that handsome young  man who they called "The King," well,  he sung too many songs, had himself  a heart attack or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest is still sitting on the bus bench. The black nurs looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be hard being a king. You know,  it's funny how you remember some  things, but some things you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gump and Forrest wait for the school bus. The bus pu up as Mrs. Gump prepares Forrest for his first day of sch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do your very best now, Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure will, Momma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the bus ride on the first  day of school very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus driver opens the door and looks down. Forrest wal to the steps of the bus and looks at the bus driver. She smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you comin' along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma said not to be taking rides  from strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the bus to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Forrest Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Dorothy Harris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now we ain't strangers anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus driver smiles as Forrest steps up into the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest steps up onto the bus. Mrs. Gump waves to Forrest the bus drives away. Forrest begins to walk down the aisl TWO YOUNG BOYS look up from the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seat's taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's taken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest looks around. A larger girl slides over so Forres can't sit next to her. She shakes her head. Forrest looks the other side where a boy sits alone on a larger seat. T boy glares up at Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's funny what a young  man recollects. 'Cause I don't  remember being born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest continues talking as he sits on the bus bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, I... don't recall what I got for  my first Christmas and I don't know  when I went on my first outdoor  picnic. But, I do remember the first  time I heard the sweetiest voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Forrest is still standing in the aisle on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...in the wide world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can sit here if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest looks back at JENNY CURRAN, a young girl about  Forrest's age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had never seen anything so beautiful  in my life. She was like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, are you gonna sit down, or  aren't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sits down next to Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with your legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, nothing at all, thank you. My  legs are just fine and dandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just sat next to her on that bus  and had conversation all the way to  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you have those shoes on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My momma said my back's crooked like  a question mark. These are going to  make me as straight as an arrow. They're my magic shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And next to Momma, no one ever talked  to me or asked me questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you stupid or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy says stupid is as stupid does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny puts her hand out toward Forrest. Forrest reaches o and shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Forrest Gump. Forrest Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From that day on, we was always  together. Jenny and me was like peas  and carrots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Jenny and Forrest run toward a large oak tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She taught me how to climb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny sits on a large branch and calls down to Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Forrest, you can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest dangles from the branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I showed her how to dangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny and Forrest sit on a tree branch and read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...a good little monkey and..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She helped me to learn how to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest hangs upside down from a branch and swings back a forth. Forrest's braces are wedged in the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I showed her to swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silhouete of the oak tree, Jenny and Forrest as they on a branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we'd just sit out and wait  for the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma's gonna worry about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny puts her hand on Forrest's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some reason, Jenny didn't never  want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Jenny. I'll stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was my most special friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest nods as he remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My only friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest continues talking to the black woman. She doesn't seem to be listening as she reads her magazine. She looks from her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, my Momma always told me that  miracles happen every day. Some people  don't think so, but they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny and Forrest walk. A dirt clod hits Forrest in the b of the head. Jenny looks as Forrest rubs his head. THREE  YOUNG BOYS get off their bikes and pick up more rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... dummy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest is hit in the eye with another dirt clod. Forrest falls backward onto the ground as the boys glare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you retarded, or just plain  stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm Forrest Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny helps Forrest back up. Boy #1 and Boy #2 throw more dirt clods at Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just run away, Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another dirt clod hits Forrest in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, Forrest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest tries to run along the road, but his braces makes impossible. He hobbles along as Jenny yells after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run away! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy #1 and Boy #2 turn back toward the bikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the bikes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys pick up their bikes and ride after Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get him! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out, dummy, here we come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys ride after Forrest. Jenny stands and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna get you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, Forrest! Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest hobbles along the dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, Forrest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest looks over his shoulder. The three boys race on t bikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back here, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest begins to run faster with his braces on. Forrest  continues running as the boys chase him. Blood drips down from a cut on his head. The boys on the bikes are gaining Forrest. Forrest hobbles along. He begins to gain speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, Forrest! Run!

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION --
dialogues.text: Forrest runs from the chasing room. He looks over his sho in fear. The boys on the bikes peddle faster as they gain on Forre running. Forrest tries to run even faster to get away. Suddenly hi braces shatter, sending steel and plastic flying into the air. Forrest runs and look down at his legs in surprise. Forrest continues to run faster as the metal braces and s fly off his legs. Forrest runs free of his braces and begins to pick up spe The chasing boys ride over the remains of Forrest's brace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you wouldn't believe it if I  told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can run like the wind blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black woman continues to read her magazine. Forrest s as he remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From that day on, if I was going  somewhere, I was running!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sprints away from the boys. The boys stop the cha and watch in disbelief. Forrest is already at the far end the road, clear of the chasing boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gettin' away! Stop him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy #1 throws his bike down in frustration. Forrest runs  across a field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest runs past a chain gang in their prison uniforms. They are cutting at the weeds on the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest runs across the street. THE TWO OLD MEN sit in fr of the barber shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That boy sure is a running fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest runs down a driveway toward Jenny's small house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now remember how I told you that  Jenny never seemed to want to go  home? Well, she lived in a house  that was as old as Alabama. Her Momma  had gone up to heaven when she was  five and her daddy was some kind of  a farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest knocks on Jenny's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny? Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest look around the field at the left. He notices Jen and runs toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a very lovin' man. He was  always kissing and touchin' her and  her sisters. And then this one time,  Jenny wasn't on the bus to go to  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest runs to Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, why didn't you come to school  today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
